>>179567515

At bottom, Avatar is a pretty simple and standard "white guy goes native" story, done a little differently. It is in a lineage with Dune, Pocahantas, Ferngully, Lawrence of Arabia, Dances with Wolves, and other narratives all ultimatley inspired by European contact with Native Americans, and colonialism more broadly. A large part of what makes it work is that it twists the thing with a sci-fi setting and that it's more visually impressive, the sheer spectacle of it.

>>179568818
> both ground armor and VTOLs have weak glass canopies that are easily punctured by fucking arrows
Na'vi are twice as big as you and exercised. Na'vi bows are made out of carbon reinforced trees, 3 meters long and recurve. A nice shot does have the chance of penetrating plexiglass (Avatar 1 showed that penetration is a rare event, when the plot needs it.)
> Uses rotary wings, no jets
The planet has a thicker atmosphere (120% of Earth), and 18% CO2. Jets need a fuck ton of Oxygen to work, and transonic behaviors are fucked up in that conditions. They would need the complete JPL there or Area 51 to try how jets would work there.
Also jets fly IFR. If you EMP them (EMP fields tend to protect high value targets like the Hallelujah Mountains), that means VFR, and that means subsonic (no human has the reaction time).
Also, the targets are under a dense forest canopy. That means no aerial intel, no positive target locks, and misfires hitting trees. You need tons of daisy cutters and primarily boots in the ground.
> No nukes
They are under corporate authority, and the public on Earth is staunchly pro-Pandora. If Pandora was nuked, BLM riots would break out, and this in addition to full scale na'vi and animal war.
> No thermobarics/napalm
Yes, when they made the landing in avatar 2 they napalmed the fuck out of the site and everything around it for miles.
> No counter insurgency
They use US tactics, equipment and doctrine. We sucked big time in Afghanistan, Nam, Iraq and Iran. All of these were occupied, and we got beaten out by insurgents.

tl;dr: Fighting in Pandora is like fighting in Nam. We didn't exactly win that one, either.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>179571293
>Again, you could say the exact same thing about how they make everyone read and write a page on The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas and To Kill a Mockingbird. Studying literature has every bit as much potential to be as biased as hyperfocused on specific social issues as you imply film does
I agree entirely. Not only should kids be reading more books, but they should ideally be reading different books to the ones currently prescribed.
But other than public service films about fire-safety or something, every single film I was shown from kindergarten to the end of high-school was a complete and utter waste of time.

Children will already watch movies in their spare time as they grow up. What they don't do much anymore is read literature. School should fill that gap, rather than show them even more films. Since the advent of television, educated people have become less-literate, not more, and I see no evidence that showing films in school is improving people's ability to think skeptically or critically either.

I don't see any need to show movies in school.

Why?

>The sheer variety of stories that surrounded Sonja gave Bassett carte blanche to pursue her own vision. “She was a blank canvas,” Bassett says. The one constant was the chain-mail bikini that had helped earn Sonja the title of sexiest woman in comics, according to Comic Buyer’s Guide, in 2011. “It’s preposterous,” says Bassett. “She became a character for prepubescent 13-year-olds that was never accessible beyond.” Bassett grins, sips her cocktail, then quickly self-corrects. “I mean, I loved it!” For the record, Bassett’s Red Sonja is keeping the chain-mail bikini.

>During casting, Millennium reached out to Game of Thrones’ Hannah John-Kamen to play Sonja, but Bassett decided to go with an unknown instead. She chose the Italian American actress and model Matilda Lutz, whose natural sincerity and warmth appealed to Bassett. “She’s a beautiful, feisty, tough, committed young woman who people are going to want to watch,” Bassett says. Lutz, who gained 13 pounds of muscle for the role, says, “Every day it’s either climbing or horseback riding or fighting.” As she understands her, Red Sonja is a “woman alone in the world, trying to survive in a very crazy environment.”

>Bassett’s script, which she rewrote half a dozen times, steers clear of sexual politics and gender. Curious and friendly in person, Bassett also is direct. “I didn’t warm to the previous script, which was much more sexual politics,” she says. “Obviously in my personal life I’m interested in that. But as a storyteller I don’t think it’s interesting.” She also eliminated a key plot point from the original 1985 film: Sonja’s rape by marauding enemies. “I have no interest in fictional women who use [rape] as an engine of motivation,” she says. “It’s not a strong motivation. She’s just a human being in the world of femininity.”

>>179550155
At least he's alive. Don't make my mistake and put him down when he gets too feeble. My chihuahua mix always had a limp and a bad back and developed breast tumors. I got locked up and the only thing that kept me from killing myself, or at least losing all hope in freedom, was the desire to return to my dog. On the inside this guy kept telling me I should have put her down like he did his dog. What a fucking callous asshole, I thought. When I got out 2 weeks later (home arrest), she was dead from her illnesses. She died sad, alone, and in pain.

I wish deeply that I was with her when she went. I wish that I hadn't caused her so much pain with my selfishness. 14 years of loyalty, and she died without me. Don't make the same mistake I did, and don't take this advice as offensive like I did. You will regret the years of unnecessary pain. I'm crying now, a grown man, just typing this down.

I always heard that getting a new pet helps with grief, but I don't know. I considered it insulting. A year later, I was burdened with a puppy. I broke down instantly. It helps. You don't forget them, but it helps.

Do right by your cat and don't be selfish. You will regret it.

you could say that about any aspect of film though; new wave stuff is incredibly authentic, often about the lack of direction and loneliness the citizens had despite being within an incredibly tight, increasingly advanced space; much of their stories exploring the many lifestyles that could be found at any given time within that space that you wouldn't even be aware of
>fear
>romance
>violence
>corruption
>loss
new wave stuff is about the discovery of the self, the characters are the most regular people imaginable; and the locations tend to serve as contrast to the reality of things: pretty lights, tall white buildings, but everyone living within that space very much lost

"authenticity" is a wide net though, it can be what this anon >>179571019 posted or fiction that looks into human condition and emotions

People keep reposting the "This machine can read your mind!" articles without reading a single line inside.
No, the scanner doesn't know what you're thinking.
The way it works is it makes you see a bunch of things, registers your reaction to each, then shows you one of those things again and goes "Ah, I've seen this reaction before! You're thinking of X!"

It's extremely limited, it can only "read" a response it has seen before in a controlled setting, and is "blind" to anything you react to in a way that's different than other times, be it because of your current mood, the thing you saw not actually being the same, or other factors.

>>179552913
What I meant was the infected in TLoU1 are like a distant third place in importance, after character development as #1 and bandits/Hunters/Fireflies/soldiers as #2. I mistakenly believed it to be a zombie game going in, back in 2015, rather than being Uncharted 3.5, which honestly I should have expected.
In the first chapter with combat, you face three Runners as minor obstacles, then fight a dozen uninfected gunmen. The ratio remains roughly the same for the rest of the game.
TLoU does this same "humans are the real monsters" stuff I've only ever personally enjoyed in Romero's first three Dead films, and even then only really Night and Day. I used to hate the biker shit in Dawn, and that's basically the entirety of TLoU.
I compare Resident Evil because I believe Clickers and Bloaters are at least partly inspired by the higher-level BOWs. Nothing about fungus inspired my comparison, though I do think VII took influence from TLoU, especially as Fat Molded are almost exactly like Bloaters. What I meant was mostly that RE always has human villains, but you're never just going to shoot Wesker or Marcus in the face; the human foes either transform into a monster, or are just long-dead already or far beyond STARS/BSAA/whoever's reach. I believe video games are "allowed" to get wackier with creature design than film/TV, so I appreciate that Capcom go hogwild with BOWs. I haven't played TLoU2 yet, but the Rat King does look like a step in the "right" direction for me, subjectively. I just hope TLoU3 can have Abby turning into a dinosaur or growing an organic chainsaw arm.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What’s your favourite movie?
Every time I share mine; I get shit on.
Roger Ebert said: “it’s a one joke movie, if it even had one joke.”
That quote essentially sums up anyones feelings who I’ve talked to about ‘fear and loathing.’
It’s not really the hallucinogen humour, or the story itself that keeps me coming back . . . As there isn’t much of a story.

It’s that despite being filmed in the 90’s; This is the most accurate depiction of the death of the 60’s I’ve seen.
The flash backs and monologues about just what the country could’ve been, had the youth movement of the 60’s not split ever increasingly apart.

The general degeneracy of having one FULL hurrah; push your way of life beyond what YOU’RE comfortable with, and rip the knob off. All to spite the fact that you’re trapped in the brutish realities of 1971; your way off life was literally lashed and stomped to death at anti-war student protests.

Trying to make a caricature of yourself, in the image of what your government pitches to citizens, as to what average ‘dope fiends’ are like . . . . Outlining just how gross an exaggeration it all is

It can be taken as funny, since everything is from the point of view of an unreliable narrator. I take it as sad, the film literally starts with “he who makes a beast of himself, gets rid of the pain of being a man.”

A way of life that values beauty, durability, sustainability, kindness, and experimentation.
In this the supposed ‘land of the free’
Beaten down, until their acid shifted gears into a survival trip on them; and they scattered like rats from a sinking ship.
Beaten by an (almost insignificant minority) of the population, who valued; cheapness, excess, accessibility, obedience, and enforcement.

This film brings me back to a time and place I wasn’t alive or there for. But of which the consequences still weights heavily on the shoulders of those born today.
It makes me sad the way it all went.

>>179571196
>“so often I get optimistic and explain the best method of learning to write to students. I don’t believe any of them has ever tried it, but I will explain it to you now. After all, you may be the exception. When I read about this method, it was attributed to Benjamin Franklin, who invented and discovered so much. Certainly I did not invent it. But I did it, and it worked. That is more than can be said for most creative writing classes. Find a very short story by a writer you admire. Read it over and over until you understand everything in it. Then read it over a lot more. Here’s the key part. You must do this. Put it away where you cannot get at it. You will have to find a way to do it that works for you. Mail the story to a friend and ask him to keep it for you, or whatever. I left the story I had studied in my desk on Friday. Having no weekend access to the building in which I worked, I could not get to it until Monday morning. When you cannot see it again, write it yourself. You know who the characters are. You know what happens. You write it. Make it as good as you can. Compare your story to the original, when you have access to the original again. Is your version longer? Shorter? Why? Read both versions out loud. There will be places where you had trouble. Now you can see how the author handled those problems. If you want to learn to write fiction, and are among those rare people willing to work at it, you might want to use the little story you have just finished as one of your models. It’s about the right length. P”
>― Gene Wolfe, The Best of Gene Wolfe

>>179563468
>>179564957
It should be noted that a major theme of Star Wars is the eternal recurrence of the same, basically a time loop.

The First Order is literally just the Empire/Republic too, although you have to piece it together from the expository dialogue and minor visual cues. For example, the opening text:

"Luke Skywalker has vanished. In his absence, the sinister FIRST ORDER has risen from the ashes of the Empire."

The phrase 'ashes of the Empire' refers to the (New) Republic - specifically a disavowed aspect of the Republic. The Republic was rebuilt on the ashes, and now (because Luke is gone) something has risen from those same ashes. The First Order is not a threat from outside. They have emerged from within the Republic. They are part of the Republic.

Note the past tense on 'risen'. The First Order is not rising; it has risen. This implies that they already rival or surpass the other Republic worlds, and the Resistance is now resisting their influence.

That doesn't happen without popular support. When we see the five Republic worlds that support Leia (only five! Out of how many in the prequels?), we're shown a typical liberal metropolis. The First Order obliterates them. It's an expression of populist rage against 'elites'. And note that even these five worlds can only covertly support Leia. Unlike Snoke, Leia does not have popular support in the Republic as a whole.

And again, General Hux says that the stormtroopers are an alternative to using clones. So, like the clones, they are merely tools deployed by the First Order - a fraction of the overall population under their leadership. The majority of First Order people are not stormtroopers. They are implicitly no different from the populations of other Republic planets.

>just shoot live action then.
live action would require hundreds of actors, costumes for all those actors, finding the right location, expensive sets, getting the permission to shot on set location, days of coaching the actors/stuntmen, etc
Espeically if you want to make a scifi or historical epic going all digital is much cheaper and easier to pull of while still looking good.
Also there are still certain things that are almost impossible to do with real actors even if you have hollywood funding. Take for example cavalry charges. Getting a bunch of horses to charge into a human formation would be impossible to film in a convincing way while still keeping the actors save.
